title: Daniel Lopez
text:
Experience

UCSD - Office for Equity, Diversity, and Inclusion

2022 - Present | San Diego, CA
Excel: Played a proactive role in gathering, intricately organizing, and meticulously analyzing data, utilizing Excel extensively. This substantial contribution significantly propelled the progress of ongoing diversity research projects.
Efficiency: Showcased adeptness in employing software and tools, including Microsoft Office and Google Suite, to handle tasks ranging from data management and intricate scheduling to facilitating streamlined communication.



Entrepreneur

2020-2023 | San Francisco, CA
Entrepreneurship: Purchased items in order to resell them for profit, with an average profit margin of 75%.
Market Research: Researched market trends to find items that would provide the highest profit margins and have low turn around times.
Excel: Used to excel to keep track of inventory, business costs, revenue, profits, return on investment, and a balance sheets.

title: [Power BI] FIFA World Cup Statistics
text:
This Power BI project analyzes FIFA World Cup data to provide comprehensive insights into team performance through interactive visualizations and data-driven narratives.

PowerBi

Overall Page
The overall page displays basic information from all FIFA World Cups

Countries Participated: Keeps count of all countries that have participated.
Games Played: Keeps count of all games that have been played.
Histogram with Sum of Goals and Year: Keeps track of goals scored in each World Cup.




All teams page
This page allows you to select a country and display their Win/Draw/Loss rate and their Goals scored and Against.

Wins/Draws/Losses chart: This pie chart displays the total games won, drawn, and lost.
Goals scored/Goals against: This pie chart displays the goals scored and the goals received by each country.





All Teams example with England selected




Year page
This page has a markdown bar that lets you select a World Cup year and presents information based on the year.

Host: Displays the respective years Banner and Golden Ball winner.
Information table: Displays the games, attendance, teams, and goals for that World Cup.
Match Schedule: Displays the match schedule for that World Cup, includes Date, Stage, Home team, Away team, and Winner.
Placement table: Table displaying the World Cup Winner of that year, second, and third place.





Year example with 2006 selected and showing markdown bar




Winners page
Alike the All Teams page this displays information for only World Cup winners.

Winners table: Displays the World Cup winners and the year they won. If they have won multiple times it will list all the years that they have won.
Wins/Draws/Losses chart: This pie chart displays the total games won, drawn, and lost.
Goals scored/Goals against: This pie chart displays the goals scored and the goals received by each country.





Winners example with Italy selected





Excel

World Cup Matches
Keeps track of all World Cup matches that have taken place. Includes statistics like year, stage, teams, score, and many more.



World Cups
This sheet keeps track of the year, host, World Cup winner, goals scored, attendance, and Golden Ball Winner.



All Team Stats
The data in this sheet is meant to track every country who has participated statistics, this includes games played, wins, losses, draws, goals scored, and goals received.



Top Team Stats
Here is the statistics for every World Cup Winner.



Top Team Images
Here I used this sheet to store the images for the first, second, and third place for every World Cup.



Hosts Images
This sheet is used to store the host poster for every World Cup.



Golden Boot Winners
This sheet is used to store images of every Golden Ball Winner.

View on GitHub

title: Daniel Lopez
text:
Hello, and thank you for visiting my personal website. I’m a senior at UCSD majoring in Business Economics, a dynamic professional with a passion for stocks, data analytics, entrepreneurship, and fostering diversity and inclusion. Let me give you a glimpse into my academic and professional journey.
Feel free to explore my website to learn more about my journey, projects, and the skills I bring to any team or project. Connect with me on LinkedIn, I’m excited about the possibilities and I look forward to connecting with you!
 
  
   
  
    
     LinkedIn
  
  
    
     GitHub

Install required libraries

library(tidyverse)

title: Pokemon Visualization Analysis (Currently In Progress)
text:
Pokemon analysis
Install required libraries

library(tidyverse)  
library(stringr)
library(gridExtra)
library(repr)







Setting colors for the region

generation_colors <- c("mistyrose", "lightblue", "moccasin", "plum",
                       "darkseagreen1" )

Bar chart showing count of Pokemon in each generation

poke_data |>
    count(Generation) |>
    ggplot(aes(x=Generation, y=n)) +                                  
    geom_bar(stat ="identity", fill=generation_colors) +                                  
    xlab("Generation") +                                              
    ylab("Number of Pokemon") +                                
    ggtitle("How many Pokemon are in each generation?") + 
    geom_label(aes(label=n)) +
    scale_x_continuous(expand = c(0,0), breaks = c(1,2,3,4,5), 
                       labels = c("Kanto","Johto","Hoenn","Sinnoh","Unova")) +
    theme_minimal()
